articles.headline: Judge in Apple Case Seen as Unfazed by Stress, Even a Plane Crash
articles.snippet: Sheri Pym, who is overseeing the case between Apple and the Justice Department, is described as unflappable, even when a plane crashed into her house.
articles.abstract: Sheri Pym, who is overseeing the case between Apple and the Justice Department, is described as unflappable, even when a plane crashed into her house.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — Just before Christmas in 2003, a twin-engine Cessna plane crashed into the Claremont, Calif., home of Sheri N. Pym. The house was destroyed and the pilot was killed.

articles.headline: The Mideast Came to Idaho State. It Wasn’t the Best Fit.
articles.snippet: College students from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have brought much-needed money to a predominantly Mormon city, but it has made for a troubled mix.
articles.abstract: College students from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have brought much-needed money to a predominantly Mormon city, but it has made for a troubled mix.
articles.lead_paragraph: POCATELLO, Idaho — When the Rev. Jim Jones, pastor of the Blazing Grace Church here, approached the lectern at City Hall, he was holding a copy of the Quran.

articles.headline: Most Republicans Feel Embarrassed by Campaign, Poll Says
articles.snippet: A majority of Republican primary voters view their party as divided, while Democratic voters see their side as unified, according to a New York Times/CBS News national poll.
articles.abstract: A majority of Republican primary voters view their party as divided, while Democratic voters see their side as unified, according to a New York Times/CBS News national poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alarmed by the harsh attacks and negative tone of their presidential contest, broad majorities of Republican primary voters view their party as divided and a source of embarrassment and think that the campaign is more negative than in the past, according to a New York Times/CBS News national poll released on Monday.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Why Sanders Trails Clinton Among Minority Voters
articles.snippet: One reason for Bernie Sanders’s gap among African-Americans is that they have more favorable impressions of the economy.
articles.abstract: One reason for Bernie Sanders’s gap among African-Americans is that they have more favorable impressions of the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Asked during a January debate why he trailed Hillary Clinton so badly among minority voters, Senator Bernie Sanders said he would gain ground once those voters became familiar with his track record and agenda on the economy and criminal justice.

articles.headline: U.S. Says It May Not Need Apple’s Help to Unlock iPhone
articles.snippet: A court hearing set for Tuesday was canceled in the Justice Department’s bid to gain access to phone data in the San Bernardino mass shooting inquiry.
articles.abstract: A court hearing set for Tuesday was canceled in the Justice Department’s bid to gain access to phone data in the San Bernardino mass shooting inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — The Justice Department said on Monday that it might no longer need Apple’s assistance in opening an iPhone used by a gunman in the San Bernardino, Calif., rampage last year.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: No Respite for Yahoo, Battling on 2 Fronts
articles.snippet: The company is trying both to quell an activist insurgency and to explore selling itself at the same time. Either would be difficult alone.
articles.abstract: The company is trying both to quell an activist insurgency and to explore selling itself at the same time. Either would be difficult alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It’s often hard to sell a company, particularly when that company has faced steady declines over the last decade, been surpassed by upstarts and is struggling in its latest turnaround plan.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Bill Ackman Bets Again on Valeant, Taking a Seat on the Board
articles.snippet: The hedge fund manager, who made billions spotting financial fraud but missed any signs of chicanery at Valeant, is hoping to salvage his investment.
articles.abstract: The hedge fund manager, who made billions spotting financial fraud but missed any signs of chicanery at Valeant, is hoping to salvage his investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: After reaping the best returns of any hedge fund manager in 2014, Bill Ackman appeared on the cover of Bloomberg Markets magazine, grinning, with the headline, “How Do You Like Bill Ackman Now?”

articles.headline: Donald Trump Pushes Serious Image in the Capital
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s whirlwind day in Washington was part of his effort to demonstrate that he is running a serious presidential campaign.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s whirlwind day in Washington was part of his effort to demonstrate that he is running a serious presidential campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump came to Pennsylvania Avenue on Monday and offered a freewheeling, circuslike glimpse of what the nation’s capital might look like if he is successful in his quest to occupy that big, white house on the 1600 block of the street.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Strikes Claimed by ISIS Shut Brussels and Shake European Security
articles.snippet: The Islamic State militant group claimed responsibility for the blasts, which occurred four days after the capture of a suspect in the Paris attacks.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State militant group claimed responsibility for the blasts, which occurred four days after the capture of a suspect in the Paris attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Bombs packed with nails terrorized Brussels on Tuesday in the deadliest assault on the European heartland since the Islamic State’s attacks on Paris four months ago, hitting the airport and subway system in coordinated strikes that were also claimed by the militant extremist group.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin, Aurelien Breeden and Anita Raghavan

articles.headline: Brussels Attacks Underscore Vulnerability of an Open European Society
articles.snippet: In an age of easy travel and rising militancy, intelligence experts fear that terrorist attacks have become an unavoidable part of life in Europe.
articles.abstract: In an age of easy travel and rising militancy, intelligence experts fear that terrorist attacks have become an unavoidable part of life in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Since the November attacks in Paris, the Belgian authorities have conducted dozens of raids, combed whole neighborhoods for well-known militants and even locked down the capital for days, all part of promises to step up efforts to root out jihadists.

articles.headline: Low Gas Prices Create a Detour on the Road to Greater Fuel Economy
articles.snippet: Automakers are expected to seek changes to mileage targets, which were set when gas prices were higher and fuel economy was more important to drivers.
articles.abstract: Automakers are expected to seek changes to mileage targets, which were set when gas prices were higher and fuel economy was more important to drivers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Since agreeing to tough new federal fuel economy standards five years ago, automakers have been methodically improving the gas mileage of their vehicles and reducing emissions harmful to the environment.
